summary:
I am an anthropologist and writer with a focus on race, racism and cultural memory.  As an activist and researcher, my mission is to mobilize academic knowledge and practical strategies for anti-oppression work. My education informs my activism, and my activism fuels my research.

I am the founder of Students of Cultural Anthropology Journal (SCAJ), a platform where students can publish their work and learn from each other. I am currently employed as manager of external affairs. I also work as a writing coach.

My academic interests include include (homo-)nationalism, whiteness, and decolonial anthropology. I enjoy music and studying languages. I want to learn more about deconstructive methods for inclusive research practices.

Born in the USA, as daughter of a Dutch mother and Israeli father, I've always been curious about 'the other'. This curiosity, my strong sense of empathy and my passion for people and culture characterise who I am. What drives me in life is helping others.

As organisational development advisor at the Municipality of the Hague, I have advised and supported in the development of the organisation in order to better help the citizens of the Hague. More recently, I set up an after-school programme for children of the township Masiphumlele (Cape Town) to help increase their opportunities in becoming role models for their community. 

I'm open-minded, eager to learn, not afraid to speak my mind and push for the best results. My strength lies in building strong relationships and focussing on the 'how', whilst getting things done.

I am open-minded and non-judgemental.
I am aware that everything I experience, read, see and hear has an influence on me and my way of thinking.  
I can work independently, and I am responsible, but I also adapt easily when working in a team.

My values: freedom, equality, engagement, reliability, quality and result-oriented.

name: Julienne Weegels
skills: ['Human Rights Research', 'University Teaching', 'Lecturing', 'Workshops', 'Latin American Studies', 'Violence', 'Prisons', 'Ethnography', 'Gender Studies', 'Anthropology', 'Creative Writing', 'Qualitative Research']
summary:
I'm assistant professor of Latin American Studies at the University of Amsterdam - Centre for Latin American Research and Documentation (CEDLA). Trained as an anthropologist, I'm specialized in ethnographic research on violence, (dis)order, (prison) governance and state-(un)making, particularly in Nicaragua. Currently I also work on these topics in the city of Amsterdam, as PI on the research project "Het Ongelijkheidsbeginsel" (the principle of inequality), which takes a holistic approach to understand the ways in which urban inequalities (spatial, socio-economic and racial/ethnic) are mitigated and/or reproduced through criminal justice interventions.

At the same time, I continue to research practices of (para-)policing, imprisonment, state crime and organized crime in Nicaragua. In relation to the 2018 protests and their aftermath, I work with (former) political prisoners and their family members, Nicaraguan exiles and refugees, and human rights activists in doing so. I am currently working on two book projects. The first is a volume I'm editing with Hanneke Stuit and Jennifer Turner, titled "Carceral Worlds", which explores the expansion of carcerality in our globalized present and how this may be unsettled. The second is a book manuscript based on my doctoral thesis, which was awarded a cum laude distinction. This thesis "Performing Prison: Power, Agency and Co-Governance in Nicaraguan Prisons" was based on 31 months of multi-sited ethnographic research conducted between 2009 and 2016 with long and short-sentenced (former) prisoners of three Nicaraguan prison facilities.

In general, I am much interested in the day-to-day workings of prison life and the (development) of carceral/penal states, policing and other forms of non-state/extralegal surveillance and governance, always with a focus on questions of power and legitimacy, violence, gender and the body. To this end, I participate actively in a number of interdisciplinary networks on confinement and prisons research, including the Global Prisons Research Network (as a co-organizer), the EASA Anthropology of Confinement Network (former co-convener), and the Americas Prisons Research Network/Red Penitenciaria de las Americas (founding member). 

I'm always open to collaborations and exchanging ideas. If you'd like to get in touch, please feel free to write me at j.h.j.weegels@uva.nl. Thank you!

name: Zina Jorna
skills: ['Evenementenplanning', 'Vrijwillligers aansturen', 'Werving', 'Interculturele communicatie', 'Administratie', 'Research', 'Communicatie', 'Adobe Creative Suite', 'Sociale media', 'Sociale wetenschappen', 'Sociologie', 'Onderzoek', 'SPSS', 'Microsoft Office', 'PowerPoint', 'Photoshop', 'Adobe Premier Pro', 'InDesign', 'Mailchimp', 'WordPress']
summary:
I am a Medical and Cultural Anthropologist who is committed to working for equality, health, sexual and reproductive health and rights, human and animal rights and environmental sustainability. The analytical and critical thinking skills I have obtained during my education have developed a strong activist mindset for these values. 

Besides research skills such as ethnographic fieldwork, interviewing and analysing data – my education and international experience have trained me in intercultural communication. I am a culturally sensitive active listener and have knowledge of strategic communication – which makes me good at understanding people with different views and cultural origins and in adapting communication for such specific audiences. 

Furthermore, I have a strong visual interest and experience in visual methods such as photography and film (editing). This is a way in which I like to combine my knowledge and activism with creativity.
 
In my free time, I volunteer to provide information about accessing safe abortion care in the Netherlands. I also contribute to raising awareness and fighting stigma through organizing and collaborating in events about abortion and reproductive justice. Furthermore, I organized a restructuring of our volunteer organisation together with a co-volunteer.

Currently, I am working for Trias Pedagogica, an organisation focused on intercultural parenting.

name: Mijke de Waardt
skills: ['Training', 'Research', 'International Organizations', 'Conflict', 'Fundraising', 'Capacity Building', 'Latin America', 'International Relations', 'Qualitative Research', 'Change Management', 'Social Sciences', 'Human Rights']
summary:
I am an anthropologist, Latin Americanist and victimologist. My research explores whether and, if so, how legal, quasi-legal and non-legal transitional justice procedures affect the daily lives of those who experienced political violence, gross human rights violations and mass victimisation.
I have a keen interest in the themes of:	
- Transitional justice, particularly the right to and politics of reparations
- Participation, citizenship, state-survivors relations in post-conflict societies
- Victim labelling and victim identities
- Human rights, international justice
- Alternative justice epistemologies and social comparison
- Ethnography, phenomenological research, participatory research, visual methods, mixed-methods
- Peru, Colombia, Cyprus, Guatemala, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Guinea-Conakry, Northern-Iraq
- Latin America

name: Priscilla Rasyid
skills: ['Project Management', 'Video Production', 'Creative Writing', 'Social Media', 'Research', 'Documentaries', 'Writing', 'Adobe Premiere Pro', 'Public Speaking', 'Organization Skills', 'Storytelling', 'Communication', 'Interviewing', 'Social Research', 'Cultural Anthropology', 'Visual Anthropology', 'Asian Studies', 'Gender Studies', 'Scriptwriting']
summary:
ENGLISH BELOW

“Grote dingen gebeuren niet alleen door een impuls, maar als een opeenvolging van kleine dingen die met elkaar verbonden zijn.” (van Gogh)

Ik geloof in de alledaagse kleine acties die voor de grootste impact kunnen zorgen. Dit kan een gesprek zijn met een vreemde in het park. Dit kan een autorit van een uur zijn met een persoon die je pas net hebt ontmoet. Het is een rimpel effect dat klein begint maar daarna zich alleen zal verspreiden als je het laat zijn. 

Als project manager verzorg ik de dagelijkse operaties zodat een mooi resultaat geleverd wordt. Ik ga door bij tegenslagen en vraag altijd “Hoe kan dit anders?”. Ik combineer een goede dosis van analytisch denken en het onderscheid maken tussen het essentiële en niet-essentiële. Verder neem ik altijd mijn enthousiasme en humor mee naar werk. 

Project management | Communicatief | Verbindend  | Creatief | Leergierig

---

"Great thing are done by a series of small things brought together" (van Gogh) 

I believe that it is small mundane actions that can generate the biggest impact. This can be a conversation with a stranger in the park. This can be a one hour car drive with a person you just met. It is a ripple effect that starts very small but can only expand if you let it be. 

As a project manager I take care of the daily operations to create a great result. When facing challenges I ask myself the question “How can I do this differently?” I combine a good dose of analytical thinking and discerning between the essential and non-essential. Further, I always make sure I bring in enthusiasm and humor to work.

Project management | Communicative | Connecting | Creative | Studious

name: Patrick van der Pas
position 1: Program Management Support/Project Manager Information Management ‘Open op Orde’
position 2: Project Manager - DE&I and Accessibility Consultant
skills: ['Project Management', 'Diversity & Inclusion', 'Human Rights', 'Communication', 'Diversity Program Development', 'Organization Skills', 'Public Policy', 'Teamwork', 'Critical Thinking', 'Business Development', 'Problem Solving', 'Leadership', 'Management', 'Cultural Diversity', 'Social Media Marketing', 'Interpersonal Skills', 'Time Management', 'Digital Marketing', 'Management Consulting', 'Curriculum Development']
summary:
Patrick van der Pas (He/They) is a well-experienced policy expert and project manager at PTRCKVDPS (+10y) in the fields of Diversity, Equity, Inclusion & Accessibility, and business development. As a change agent, they love solving complex social and cultural policy challenges and projects. 

By exploring the dynamics of contexts from a multidisciplinary perspective, Patrick van der Pas contributed to the success of different projects and companies in a wide range of industries. In 2021, Patrick was a Senior Human Rights Officer for Copenhagen 2021 where they organized a 3-day hybrid Human Rights Conference with multiple plenary sessions and over 60 break-out sessions for over 2.500 participants, which brought together activists, corporates, governmental officials such as ministers and heads of states, and over 300 organizations globally. Fun fact: Patrick wrote the keynote speech for Her Royal Highness The Crown Princess of Denmark at the opening ceremony. Additionally, Patrick contributed to the realization of other events in the name of WorldPride and EuroGames such as the Interparliamentary Plenary Assembly and the Embassy Engagement Program.

Other highlights of Patrick's career are their role as Project Manager for Global Pride 2020, bringing together hundreds of organizations, artists, and state officials from all 7 continents, reaching an audience of 57 million people worldwide. He created strong collaborations with big tech companies such as YouTube, Google, Sony Music, and Meta, to utilize their platforms for the event. Furthermore, Patrick prepared a policy analysis and lobby strategy report for WordProof, analyzing European privacy laws and policies on blockchain technology, and how these technologies can contribute to advancing internet safety. 

Starting at the most practical-oriented education level Patrick van der Pas worked his way to a double master’s degree in Public Policy and Human Development from Maastricht University and United Nations University. Another highlight of Patrick’s educational trajectory is the fact that they successfully completed three minors during their bachelor's in Cultural Anthropology and Development Sociology; 1) Global Health, Care & Society, 2) Gender & Sexuality, and 3) Governance and Policy. 

In their pastime, Patrick van der Pas is a Human Rights advocate working in the international civic & social organization industry for over ten years and always looking for new challenges.

name: Renske Bakker Schut
summary:
I am a cultural anthropologist, occupational therapist and film maker. This mix makes me a young, versatile professional who is passionate about telling the stories behind people and helping them move forward in life.

After I had completed my bachelor in occupational therapy, I decided to specialize in visual anthropology to dive deeper into the stories behind people. Currently I am working on my master research and film, in which I explore the concept "sense of place" in a care institution in The Hague. After I have finished my master’s programme in summer 2023, I will be ready to combine my knowledge of anthropology, visual methods and occupational therapy into a future occupation!
